text: England has seen the biggest relaxation
of the lockdown since it was imposed ten
weeks ago with as many as six people
allowed to meet outdoors together there
has been criticism from some scientists
that this is too much too soon a key
part of easing the lockdown is the
government's ability to identify and to
tackle outbreaks of coronavirus through
a new system of contact tracing the
prime minister promised that the system
in england would be up and running and
successful from today but there have
been quite a few complaints that it is
not ready a further hundred and eleven
deaths were reported in the last 24 hour
period and it comes as an additional
four hundred and forty-five deaths were
added after a delay in reporting that
they were linked to coronavirus and it
takes the official number of people
who've died in the UK after testing
positive for kovat nineteen to thirty
nine thousand and forty five so with the
latest on the easing of the lockdown
here's a health editor
Hugh Pym enjoying new freedom in England
today to meet outdoors in larger groups
with social distancing the rules in
Wales changed today as well Scotland and
Northern Ireland have already loosened
the guidelines on meeting outdoors so as
the restrictions are eased how will the
authorities monitor the spread of the
virus and try to keep it in check a full
testing and contact tracing system is
seen as essential as well as testing
people ministers say tracking down
recent contacts of those who test
positive will be vital to stopping the
spread of the virus contact tracers have
been appointed and the system launched
but already there are concerns one
contact traitor who wanted to be
anonymous told us he'd been given very
little work since the launch last
Thursday I haven't actually got much to
do I haven't really done anything today
I had one call on Saturday other than
that I haven't called anyone so far I'm
earning 1500 pounds a month which is
quite good for sitting on my arse doing
nothing we've heard reports from some
contact tracers that since they started
work in England last Thursday they've
had very little if anything to do what
do you think's actually happening with
the system we've
as you know 25,000 people to work as
contact tracers and the level of
incidence of disease has come down and
so so actually we we have more capacity
than we need this is a this is a good
thing they were pressed for the numbers
of people so far contacted and said
those figures would be available soon
then there's the our that's the virus
reproduction number this shows how fast
the virus is spreading anything above
one is when an individual's infecting
more than one other person the aim is to
keep it below that which means the virus
is receding the latest official estimate
is arranged between naught point seven
and naught point nine which doesn't
leave much head room data on infections
and deaths will be closely scrutinized
the daily number of new cases has been
falling the line shows the rolling
average that's the trend though this
doesn't include people who haven't been
tested that's thousands more the figure
four reported deaths has also been
coming down steadily but the rolling
average has stalled in the last few days
in the last week or two we've seen a
relatively persistent studying of the
death numbers and a very long tail if
you like of this epidemic curve so we'll
be will be watching very closely to see
if that's maintained and very persistent
or if even that increases in coming
weeks an extra four hundred and forty
five deaths have been added to the total
because of delayed reporting in previous
weeks one health leader has said this is
a dangerous moment and easing of
lockdown measures should be
painstakingly slow as scientists watch
developments Hugh Pym BBC News now
Scotland's lockdown guidelines could be
enforced by new laws if they are floated
by a minority of people that's according
to the First Minister Nicola Sturgeon
restrictions were relaxed on Friday
allowing more people to meet outdoors
the first minister said that the vast
majority had complied with
recommendations not to travel and to
keep gathering small but she said a
minority had ignored the rules some
children in England have gone back to
school today as the government eases the
lockdown and lifts some restrictions on
movement
fools are being asked to welcome
children in reception year 1 and year 6
some nurseries have opened two schools
have kept their doors open throughout
the lockdown for vulnerable children and
those of key workers our education
editor Brandon Jeffries has been to a
primary school in Tamworth in
Staffordshire at this school a welcome
organised to run like clockwork first to
arrive year six for Riley and his mum
Louise relief that he's back for his
last term even though he's gonna be back
for what about six seven weeks tops and
then have another six weeks off it's
still nice for him to go and get a
little bit learning because we couldn't
get a lot done at home I think I'm not
gonna actually like be with my friends
as much as I used to be but this is the
poignant reality of Riley's new class no
hugs no quiet jokes to friends instead
the loneliness of social distancing into
a classroom each to a single desk no
books or pens shared from lockdown to
the new rules of school even assembly is
now online from the head teachers office
to the classrooms the first job to
reassure the children most year 6 pupils
were here today but some parents of
reception all year one children kept
them home they know that school doesn't
look normal I think there's still fear
in terms of the pandemic that we're
going through I'm hoping that the more
we can show that school is successfully
open at the moment and it is safe that
more parents will send their children
back through the day washing their hands
even breaktime in the same small group
so they're back with some of their
friends but having to keep their
distance and they can't mix with any
other children in
school so although this is a day that
many of them will have been looking
forward to it's not back to school as
normal it's a bit strange we're more
spaced out whereas we usually look quite
close together makes me look happier
because I know I get to like to see the
people that I've been with my whole
entire life in Wales there is no date
for schools to open Scotland and
Northern Ireland start their return in
August under the trees lessons outdoors
will be more common one of the many
precautions at this school but still
warnings England has taken this step too
soon but we're following the scientists
who tell us that it's too soon that
contact tracing isn't working and to say
that in a fortnight's time contact
tracing could be working and the level
of infection could be half what it is
now for Riley the end of a tiring but
rewarding day still absorbing how
different school looks now Bronwyn
Jeffries BBC news
